courseTitle: Dichotomous Keys: Cells and Viruses (Dry Lab)

pageData.text: There are two broad categories of cells: <button class='glossary-text'>prokaryotes</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>eukaryotes</button>. Viruses are noncellular infectious particles with certain similarities to living cells. Students will learn the key characteristics of cells and viruses and identify simulated examples using <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous keys</button>. Students will then create and use their own dichotomous keys.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Dichotomous Keys: Cells and Viruses (Dry Lab)

text: State the purpose of a <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous key</button>.
Describe the primary characteristics of prokaryotic cells, eukaryotic cells, and viruses.
Use dichotomous keys to identify viruses and cell types.
Create a dichotomous key and demonstrate its application.

pageData.text: There are many different causes of illness. Some, like the common cold or smallpox, are caused by viruses. Others, like malaria, are caused by microscopic organisms. And then there are diseases like cancer that are caused by our own cells. Cancer is a disease caused by the uncontrolled division of abnormal cells in the body. Modern science has eradicated, and allows us to cure, many diseases; however, in the United States, cancer is on the rise. It is predicted that by 2040, the number of new cancer cases per year will rise to 29.5 million. Will science ever eliminate cancer as a public health concern?

According to Harvard Public Health<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>, the answer is no: it is not possible to eradicate cancer. Unlike virus-caused diseases, which can be prevented by a vaccine, cancers are not caused by a single factor. The risk of developing some cancers can be reduced by making healthy lifestyle choices (i.e., not smoking and exercising regularly); however, unfortunately, most cancers are caused by environmental factors and genetics. Harvard Public Health suggests that instead of focusing on eradicating cancer, the focus should be placed on its prevention, early detection, and individualized treatments.

1Drexler, M. (2022). The cancer miracle isn’t a cure. Harvard Public Health.
https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/magazine/magazine_article/the-cancer-miracle-isnt-a-cure-its-prevention/

pageData.desc: A twisted ribbon representing cancer awareness.
pageData.altText: A twisted ribbon representing cancer awareness.

pageData.text: The cell is the fundamental structural and functional unit of all living things. There are two major categories of organisms based on cell type: and . Prokaryotes include bacteria and archaea, and are characterized by the lack of a or other membranous . Eukaryotes include animals, plants, protists, and fungi, and are composed of nucleated cells with a variety of membranous organelles. All cells—prokaryotes and eukaryotes alike—possess three main components: a , a , and genetic material. The components of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells are summarized in Table 1.

pageData.subTitle: Cytoplasm
pageData.text: The cytoplasm occupies the area between the nucleus and the cell membrane. It includes aqueous fluid with dissolved ions and proteins; the protein filaments and tubules of the cytoskeleton; and, in eukaryotes, a variety of organelles—specialized structures devoted to specific cellular tasks. Prokaryotic cells generally lack such specialization.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Membrane
pageData.text: The cell membrane, also called the , surrounds and defines each cell and separates its internal environment from the external environment. The cell membrane of most bacterial and eukaryotic cells is composed primarily of two layers of phospholipid molecules. A phospholipid molecule consists of a glycerol skeleton with two fatty acids and a phosphate group attached.

The cell membranes of archaea are biochemically different from those of bacteria and eukaryotes. The phospholipid molecules contain a distinctive version of glycerol that is bound not to fatty acids but to carbon chains called <button class='glossary-text'>isoprenoids</button>. Isoprenoids can interact with one another in ways that fatty acids cannot. As a result, the membranes of certain archaea have unique properties, giving them the ability to live in environments that are extremely hot or salty.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Walls
pageData.text: Some types of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have additional layers located beyond the <button class='glossary-text'>cell membrane</button>. One such layer is a <button class='glossary-text'>cell wall</button>, which allows the cell to resist changes in osmotic pressure. The cell wall also allows the individual cell to maintain a definite shape.

Figure 1 depicts a variety of different bacterial shapes. The (plural, cocci) shape is spherical and is represented by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus. The (plural, bacilli) is rod-shaped and is represented by Streptobacillus moniliformis, Legionella pneumophila, and Salmonella typhi.

Certain bacilli, such as Clostridium botulinum and Clostridium tetani, have a club-like shape due to the development of a tough, resistant internal structure called an endospore, which allows the bacterium to become dormant in unfavorable environmental conditions. Other bacilli are curved, such as the short, helical Helicobacter pylori and the comma-shaped Vibrio cholerae. There are even bacteria with a spiral shape. Spirilla (singular, ) are rigid spirals, while , such as Treponema pallidum, are flexible.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Drawings of representative examples of bacterial cell shapes and arrangements; endospores and flagella are also shown.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Drawings of representative examples of bacterial cell shapes and arrangements; endospores and flagella are also shown.

pageData.text: Just outside the of a bacterial cell, the periplasmic space contains a gelatinous material called periplasm (Figure 2). In bacteria, numerous layers of a polymer called peptidoglycan lie outside the periplasmic space. bacteria have just a few layers of peptidoglycan located in the periplasmic space. Gram-negative bacteria also have an outer membrane that gram-positive bacteria lack, which is often linked to peptidoglycan by lipoproteins. The membrane includes specialized proteins called : water-filled channels that permit the diffusion of ions and small water-soluble molecules. The external face of the outer membrane includes lipopolysaccharide molecules, which trigger strong immune responses in humans and animals. Archaea also can have , although they do not contain peptidoglycan; thus, they are not described as gram-positive or gram-negative.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Two drawings showing the differences between cell walls of gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two drawings showing the differences between cell walls of gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria.

feedbackData.text: Gram-negative bacteria have an outer membrane that gram-positive bacteria lack, which is often linked to peptidoglycan by lipoproteins.

pageData.question: Which of the following molecules is found in gram-negative bacteria but not in gram-positive bacteria?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Gram-negative bacteria have an outer membrane, which includes specialized proteins called porins: water-filled channels that permit the diffusion of ions and small water-soluble molecules.

pageData.text: Among the , plants, fungi, and some protists have . A typical plant cell wall is shown in Figure 3. Plant cell walls contain a polymer called . There are passageways between the walls of adjacent cells called plasmodesmata (singular, ) that contain . The cell walls of fungi lack cellulose, but instead contain a polymer called . Some protists have cell walls composed of cellulose, such as green algae, and others have mineral-containing cell walls, such as diatoms. There are protists, such as amoebas and slime molds, that lack cell walls altogether.
Animal cells never have cell walls. A typical animal cell is shown in Figure 4.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A typical plant cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A typical plant cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A typical animal cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A typical animal cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.

pageData.subTitle: Genetic Material
pageData.text: The genetic material of a prokaryotic cell resides in its <button class='glossary-text'>cytoplasm</button>. A typical <button class='glossary-text'>prokaryote</button> has a single DNA molecule organized into a circular chromosome.

In a eukaryotic cell, most of the DNA is separated from the cytoplasm in a structure called the <button class='glossary-text'>nucleus</button>. When a eukaryotic cell is not preparing for division, the genetic material exists in the form of a threadlike complex of DNA and proteins known as chromatin. When the cell goes through the process of division, the chromatin coils up tightly to form compact structures called chromosomes. Within the nucleus lies at least one nucleolus. This is where <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button>—the machinery of protein synthesis—are assembled. The contents of the nucleus are separated from the rest of the cell by the nuclear <button class='glossary-text'>envelope</button>. This double membrane is penetrated by nuclear pores that permit materials to pass in and out of the nucleus.

pageData.subTitle: Organelles
pageData.text: All cells contain at least some specialized structures to carry out activities of the cell (see <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>). Both prokaryotes and <button class='glossary-text'>eukaryotes</button> have ribosomes, which carry out protein synthesis. In a prokaryote, the ribosomes are suspended in the cytoplasm. In a eukaryotic cell, some ribosomes reside in the cytoplasm but others are attached to a membranous <button class='glossary-text'>organelle</button> called the <button class='glossary-text'>rough endoplasmic reticulum</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figures 3</button> and <button class='resource-text'>4</button>), which processes and transports proteins synthesized by the affixed ribosomes.

Eukaryotes are distinguished from prokaryotes by the presence of organelles made up of membranes that are similar in structure to the of the cell, such as the rough endoplasmic reticulum. They include the , which functions in lipid and carbohydrate metabolism as well as detoxification reactions. The accepts proteins from the rough endoplasmic reticulum for additional processing and transport, especially if those proteins will be secreted from the cell. Most eukaryotic cells contain mitochondria (singular, ), double-membrane organelles that produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the energy molecule of cells. Plant cells and certain protists, such as algae, also have double-membrane organelles called , where photosynthesis occurs. are membranous organelles that store food or water; plant cells usually have a large central vacuole for water storage (Figure 3). are small membrane-bounded organelles that function in the breakdown of fatty acids, and , present in almost all animal cells (Figure 4), contain enzymes that break down a variety of biological molecules.

pageData.subTitle: Cytoskeleton
pageData.text: Cells possess a network of protein filaments and tubules called the cytoskeleton. In <button class='glossary-text'>eukaryotes</button>, the three main components of the cytoskeleton are <button class='glossary-text'>microfilaments</button>, which are responsible for cytokinesis, changes in cell shape, and cell motility; <button class='glossary-text'>intermediate filaments</button>, which provide strength and support for cells and tissues; and <button class='glossary-text'>microtubules</button>, which function in cell motility, intracellular transport, and chromosomal movements during cell division. The cytoskeleton of a prokaryotic cell is made up of different proteins but shares many of the same functions.

Some cells can move through their environment using the cytoskeleton. Many, but not all, have appendages called that extend beyond the and propel the cell along. A flagellated bacterial cell () may have a single flagellum (Vibrio cholerae) or a few flagella (Helicobacter pylori). When the flagella are located on one end of the cell, their arrangement is described as polar. Some bacteria have numerous flagella distributed all over the cell, such as Salmonella typhi. There are even with internal flagella (Treponema pallidum), which cause the cell to move in a twisting corkscrew fashion. However, many bacterial species lack flagella altogether.

There are eukaryotic cells with flagella, such as animal sperm cells and certain protists. The flagellum of a eukaryotic cell contains microtubules and whips back and forth to move the cell. Eukaryotic flagella tend to be relatively long but not very numerous. Some eukaryotic cells have similar motility structures called <button class='glossary-text'>cilia</button> that also contain microtubules but are shorter and more numerous than flagella. The protist Paramecium, as well as the epithelial cells that line the nasal cavity, have cilia.

Some eukaryotic cells move by the restructuring of microfilaments. This enables the cells to send out long projections of the <button class='glossary-text'>cytoplasm</button> covered in a <button class='glossary-text'>cell membrane</button>, known as <button class='glossary-text'>pseudopodia</button>. Amoebas are protists that move and feed using pseudopodia. Likewise, certain white blood cells move and engulf harmful microbes in this manner to protect the body from infection.

pageData.subTitle: Viruses
pageData.text: Unlike bacteria, archaea, and , viruses are acellular particles and are not generally considered to be living organisms. However, they share some of the same characteristics of living cells and can infect all types of cellular life.Most viruses are smaller than cells, ranging from approximately 20 to 300 nanometers (nm) in diameter. In contrast, Escherichia coli, a common bacterium, is about 0.25 to 1.0 micrometers (μm) in diameter. A mature human red blood cell is about 6.2 to 8.2 μm in diameter.A typical virus consists of genetic material enclosed in a lipid-protein capsule, or . There are different capsid shapes (Figure 5): helical, polyhedral, and complex. A complex capsid shape may resemble a combination of a helical and polyhedral capsid.Some viruses also have an surrounding the capsid. The envelope is composed of proteins, lipids, and sugars. Specific proteins in the envelope allow the virus to identify and infect specific cell types. The outer appearance of the virus depends on whether it is “naked” (without an envelope) or enveloped. Many enveloped viruses have a spherical appearance. For example, the influenza virus in Figure 5 is spherical due to its envelope, which surrounds and conceals a helical capsid.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Drawings of naked viruses with different capsid shapes and an enveloped virus.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Drawings of naked viruses with different capsid shapes and an enveloped virus.

pageData.text: Viruses lack reproductive structures; to replicate, they must infect a suitable host cell and hijack the host’s replication structures. Viral genomes consist of either DNA or RNA, and can be segmented or unsegmented. If the genetic material is single-stranded RNA, it is referred to as a positive strand or a negative strand, depending on the direction in which the replication enzymes read the genetic code.

pageData.subTitle: Dichotomous Keys
pageData.text: It can be challenging to distinguish all the features and characteristics of a type of organism or a cellular particle; however, a can be used to facilitate this process. A dichotomous key is a tool for identifying items (in this case, cellular organisms or viruses) based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptors. With each choice, the user is directed to another choice, ultimately leading to one that definitively identifies the item (such as a cell or virus).

pageData.question: Viruses use which of the following strategies to reproduce, despite their lack of reproductive machinery?

options.text: Viruses infect host cells and hijack their machinery.
Viruses infect host cells and replicate their mitochondria.
Viruses bind to host cells and extract their genome.
Viruses inject host cells with replication enzymes.
Viruses surround host cells with a capsid.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Viruses lack reproductive machinery; in order to replicate they must infect a suitable host cell and use the host’s replication machinery.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid description of a viral genome?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the viral genome is single-stranded RNA, it is referred to as a positive strand or a negative strand, depending on the direction in which the replication enzymes read the genetic code.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Unlike eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea, and viruses are acellular, and there is an ongoing debate over whether they can be classified as living organisms. Viruses generally consist of genetic material enclosed in a lipid-protein capsule, or capsid. Some viruses also have an envelope surrounding the capsid. The envelope is composed of proteins, lipids, and sugars derived from the virus and the host cell. Specific proteins in the envelope allow the virus to identify and infect specific cell types. Viruses lack reproductive structures; to replicate, they must infect a suitable host cell and hijack the host’s replication structures. Viral genomes consist of either DNA or RNA and can be segmented or unsegmented. If the genetic material is single-stranded, it is referred to as a positive-strand or a negative strand.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Unlike eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea, and viruses are acellular, and there is an ongoing debate over whether they can be classified as living organisms. Viruses generally consist of genetic material enclosed in a lipid-protein capsule, or capsid. Some viruses also have an envelope surrounding the capsid. The envelope is composed of proteins, lipids, and sugars derived from the virus and the host cell. Specific proteins in the envelope allow the virus to identify and infect specific cell types. Viruses lack reproductive structures; to replicate, they must infect a suitable host cell and hijack the host’s replication structures. Viral genomes consist of either DNA or RNA and can be segmented or unsegmented. If the genetic material is single-stranded, it is referred to as a positive-strand or a negative strand.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, print the tracing guide. In activity 1, you will design a prokaryotic cell, a eukaryotic cell and a virus. You will then use the dichotomous key given to identify the type of organism you designed. Then, photograph your designs. In activity 2, you will create a dichotomous key for your chose group. Then, you will test your key to make sure it correctly identifies each group member. If your key does not correctly identify each group member, revise and retest your key until it correctly identifies all group members.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a function of the cell membrane?

options.text: It allows transport of materials into and out of the cell.
It provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment.
It packages and transports proteins and lipids for transport within the cell.
It digests foreign materials and unwanted organelles in the cytoplasm.
It provides storage space for food or water.

assestmentData.question: Which component belongs to viruses, not cells?
Which term is used for rigid-spiral shaped bacterial cells?
Some eukaryotic cells move by the restructuring of microfilaments.  This enables the cells to send out long projections of the cytoplasm covered in cell membrane.  What are these projections called?
Which of the following best describes the structure of a dichotomous key?

options.text: a series of choices between pairs of descriptors
a series of choices between photographs of items
a folded paper object that mimics the shape of a living organism
a collection of objects grouped by their similarities
a graphical representation of the differences between pairs of objects

assestmentData.question: What is the primary function of centrioles?

options.text: They participate in chromosome separation during cell division.
They house the genetic material of the cell.
They translate messenger RNA into protein.

assestmentData.question: What are the three main components of the cytoskeleton in a eukaryotic cell?
What component is present in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?
Which of the following is generally NOT considered a living organism?
What is the primary function of the Golgi apparatus?

options.text: It packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport within the cell.
It translates messenger RNA into protein.
It provides storage space for food and water.

pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities thoroughly.
Collect all the necessary materials for this investigation. Print the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide.

In Activity 1, you will use the structures provided in the tracing guide to design a prokaryotic cell, a eukaryotic cell and a virus. You will then use <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous keys</button> to classify each of your designs.

typeBefore.text: There are no right or wrong choices as long as the guidelines below are followed. After each cell or virus has been created, you will identify it using the <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous key</button>.

pageData.text: Select a cell shape (number 1, 2, or 3 on the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide), and draw it on a sheet of paper. This shape represents the .
Most prokaryotes have <button class='glossary-text'>cell walls</button>. Draw a thick line around the cell membrane to represent the cell wall.

Draw a magnified view of a small section of the cell membrane and cell wall (number 35 in the tracing guide). Make a tiny box around this section,and draw lines connecting this box to a larger box. The larger box is called an inset, and it is a magnified view of the contents of the smaller box.

Choose from among the following options: a basic cell membrane (number 38) or a cell membrane with isoprene units (number 39). If the prokaryote has a basic cell membrane, draw either the <button class='glossary-text'>gram-positive</button> (number 36) or <button class='glossary-text'>gram-negative</button> (number 37) image in the inset box. These insets include representations of both the cell wall and cell membrane.
Add the standard prokaryotic cellular components inside the cell. Remember that prokaryotes have circular DNA (number 9) and <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button> (number 11).

Some prokaryotes possess a means of locomotion. A single flagellum (number 19), two polar <button class='glossary-text'>flagella</button> (number 20), or multiple flagella (number 21) may be selected and added to the drawing.
Color the remaining space inside the cell to represent the <button class='glossary-text'>cytoplasm</button> and cytoskeleton.
Label all parts of the prokaryote.
Select a cell shape (numbers 1 to 8 on the tracing guide), and draw it on the blank paper. This shape represents the eukaryotic cell membrane.
Draw a magnified view of a section of the cell membrane. Draw the basic cell membrane (number 38) with a magnified inset box.
Decide whether the cell has a cell wall. If it does have a cell wall, draw a thick line around the shape or cell membrane. Cells that lack a rigid structure cannot have cell walls.

Add the standard eukaryotic cell components to the cell. Be sure to include double-stranded DNA inside a nuclear membrane (number 10), ribosomes (number 11), mitochondria (number 12), endoplasmic reticulum (number 14), <button class='glossary-text'>Golgi apparatus</button> (number 15), and <button class='glossary-text'>lysosomes</button> and vesicles (number 16).

Some eukaryotic cells also have other internal <button class='glossary-text'>organelles</button>. One or more organelles can be added. Options include centrioles (number 13), <button class='glossary-text'>vacuoles</button> (number 17), and <button class='glossary-text'>chloroplasts</button> (number 18).

Some eukaryotic cells possess a means of locomotion, which can be added to the cell drawing. The amoeboid shape (number 8), which has no rigid structure, can only be paired with the pseudopod (number 22). If you selected any other cell shape, <button class='glossary-text'>cilia</button> or flagella may be added. Cilia (number 23) may be found around all or part of the perimeter of the cell. Alternatively, the cell may have one flagellum (number 19), two flagella (number 20), or many flagella (number 21).
Color the remaining space inside the cell to represent the cytoplasm and cytoskeleton.
Label all parts of the eukaryotic cell.

Select the shape of the viral <button class='glossary-text'>capsid</button> from among the choices on the tracing guide: polyhedral (number 24), helical (number 26), or complex “tailed polyhedral” (number 28). Draw the selected capsid shape on the paper.

Certain polyhedral and helical viruses have an <button class='glossary-text'>envelope</button>. If the capsid is polyhedral or helical, an envelope may be added. The envelope is represented by a thick line around the capsid (as shown in numbers 25 and 27).

Add a viral genome (numbers 29 to 34). First, choose either DNA or RNA. Then decide whether the genomic material is single- or double-stranded. If it is single-stranded, it is important to note the direction in which the genetic information is read by replication enzymes. Draw a small plus sign (+) or minus sign (–) beside the genomic material. Is the material segmented or unsegmented?

typeBefore.title:
D
 Use of the Dichotomous Keys (4 steps)

pageData.text: Now identify each cell and virus you created. Use the Dichotomous Keys to determine whether the drawing depicts a prokaryote, a <button class='glossary-text'>eukaryote</button>, or a virus.

Find the most similar cell or virus by starting at Steps 1a and 1b under “Is it a prokaryote, eukaryote, or virus?” and following the steps until an example of the cell or virus is found. The drawing will not indicate whether the cell wall is made of <button class='glossary-text'>chitin</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cellulose</button>, or silica, but other indicators should help the decision process to properly identify the cell or virus.
Label each drawing with the most similar cell or virus example you find based on the background text and the dichotomous keys.
Take a picture of each cell and virus you created, labeled, and identified.

pageData.title: Eukaryotes, Prokaryotes, and Viruses Dichotomous Keys
Table 2. Type of Life Dichotomous Key is it a prokaryote, eukaryote, or virus?

tableData.text:

pageData.text: Now that you have used a <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous key</button> to identify cells and viruses, in Activity 2 you will create your own dichotomous key to classify a group of living or nonliving items.

typeBefore.text: Your instructor may assign a specific group of items or leave the choice up to you. Please consult your instructor’s directions for this activity. Keep in mind that different individuals may create somewhat different, yet correct, <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous keys</button> for the same group of items. A dichotomous key is functional as long as it can be used for accurate identification. Ideally, a dichotomous key will accomplish this identification with a minimal number of paired decision statements.
Follow these guidelines to create your dichotomous key:

pageData.text:
Begin with general statements.
  1. For example, in Activity 1, the initial statements enabled you to determine if the item was a , , or virus.

As the key progresses, use more specific statements to narrow down the possibilities for identification.
  1. In Activity 1, once a cell was determined to be a prokaryote, it was possible to assess and type, which immediately eliminated some of the possible choices. Only then did you encounter decision statements about cell shape and number/arrangement of .

Whenever possible, limit the number of statements pertaining to a single characteristic.
  1. In a very basic dichotomous key, there are pairs of opposing statements for each characteristic under consideration. For an example, see statements 6a and 6b in the Virus Dichotomous Key.
  2. However, when there are several variations in a characteristic, multiple statements may occasionally be used, as in statements 1a through 1e in the Eukaryote Dichotomous Key.
  3. To make the dichotomous key easy to use, use exactly two opposing statements for a given characteristic whenever possible. If multiple statements are necessary, try to keep the number for any given characteristic as low as possible.

Use observable physical characteristics as the basis for the key statements.
  1. In Activity 1, these characteristics include cell walls, , genomic structure, and overall shape.

Ensure that all items in your group are identified.
  1. The dichotomous keys used in Activity 1 were designed to apply to all cellular life and to viruses as well. Since the number of possibilities is so great, some statements lead to an “unidentified” option. For your dichotomous key, you will have a smaller collection of items to classify. Thus, for your dichotomous key to be complete, all items must be identified.

Test your dichotomous key.
  1. The best way to ensure that your dichotomous key is functional is to give it to another person to use to identify the same or a similar set of items.
There is no disposal or cleanup necessary for this investigation.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.text:
Insert the photos of your cell and virus drawings in the appropriate sections below. Each drawing should have the listed structures indicated.Prokaryote
  • cell membrane type
  • circular DNA
  • ribosomes
  • flagellum (if applicable)
Click on the browse button to upload the file

Eukaryote
  • double-stranded DNA inside a nuclear membrane
  • ribosomes
  • mitochondria
  • endoplasmic reticulum
  • lysosomes
  • Golgi apparatus
  • vesicles
  • optional internal organelles
  • means of locomotion (if applicable)
Click on the browse button to upload the file

Virus
  • capsid shape
  • DNA or RNA, if it is single stranded or double stranded, and the replication direction
Click on the browse button to upload the file

text: Based on your drawings, which has the most complex structure: eukaryotes, prokaryotes, or viruses? Which has the simplest structure?

pageData.text: Copy and paste your dichotomous key into the space below or upload a photo of your key.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

tableData.text: Genetic material
Instructions for protein synthesis
Present
Present
Cell membrane
Separates the intracellular components from the extracellular environment and allows transport in and out of the cell; also called the plasma membrane
Present
Present
Cell wall
Provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment, especially from changes in osmotic pressure
Present in most
Present in some
Ribosomes
Translate messenger RNAs into proteins; may be free in the cytoplasm or bound to rough endoplasmic reticulum
Present
Present
Nucleus
Houses most of the genetic material
Absent
Present
Golgi apparatus
Packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell
Absent
Present
Rough endoplasmic reticulum
Has attached ribosomes; processes and transports proteins synthesized by these ribosomes
Absent
Present
Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
Assists in lipid and carbohydrate metabolism; involved in detoxification reactions
Absent
Present
Lysosomes
Digest foreign materials and unwanted organelles in the cytoplasm
Absent
Present
Mitochondria
Produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP
Absent
Present
Chloroplasts
Harness energy used for the synthesis of biological molecules, such as carbohydrates
Absent
Present in some
Centrioles
Microtubular structures that participate in chromosome separation during cell division
Absent
Present in some
Vacuoles
Provide storage space for food or water
Absent
Present in some
Flagella
Locomotion
Present in some
Present in some
Cilia
Locomotion
Absent
Present in some

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Drawings of representative examples of bacterial cell shapes and arrangements; endospores and flagella are also shown.
Figure 2: Two drawings showing the differences between cell walls of gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Parts of a plant cell
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A typical plant cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Parts of an animal Cell
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A typical animal cell diagram, which shows the major structural components of the cell.
Figure 5: Drawings of naked viruses with different capsid shapes and an enveloped virus.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, print the tracing guide. In activity 1, you will design a prokaryotic cell, a eukaryotic cell and a virus. You will then use the dichotomous key given to identify the type of organism you designed. Then, photograph your designs. In activity 2, you will create a dichotomous key for your chose group. Then, you will test your key to make sure it correctly identifies each group member. If your key does not correctly identify each group member, revise and retest your key until it correctly identifies all group members.

tableData.text:
1. The cell has one or two flagella. … Example: Planococcus citreus
  2. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Micrococcus luteus

a. The cell has one or two flagella. … Example: Planococcus citreus
b. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Micrococcus luteus

tableData.text:
1. The cell has multiple flagella. … Example: Listeria monocytogenes
  2. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Bacillus megaterium

a. The cell has multiple flagella. … Example: Listeria monocytogenes
b. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Bacillus megaterium

tableData.text:
1. The cell is spherical (coccus) and lacks flagella. … Example: Neisseria meningitidis
  2. The cell is rod shaped (bacillus). … Go to 6.
  3. The cell is spiral-shaped. … Go to 7.
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell is spherical (coccus) and lacks flagella. … Example: Neisseria meningitidis
b. The cell is rod shaped (bacillus). … Go to 6.
c. The cell is spiral-shaped. … Go to 7.

tableData.text:
1. The cell has multiple flagella. … Example: Helicobacter pylori
  2. The cell has a single flagellum. … Example: Vibrio cholerae
  3. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Escherichia coli
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has multiple flagella. … Example: Helicobacter pylori
b. The cell has a single flagellum. … Example: Vibrio cholerae
c. The cell lacks flagella. … Example: Escherichia coli

tableData.text:
1. The cell is a flexible spiral with internal flagella (spirochete). … Example: Treponema pallidum
  2. The cell is a rigid spiral with external flagella (spirillum). … Example: Rhodospirillum rubrum

  2. The cell has a cuboidal shape. … Go to 4.
  3. The cell has a columnar shape. … Go to 5.
  4. The cell has an elliptical shape. … Go to 6.
  5. The cell has no rigid structure. … Go to 8.

e. The cell has no rigid structure. … Go to 8.

tableData.text:
1. The cell has a cell wall made of silica, and has vacuoles and chloroplasts. …Example: diatom
  2. The cell has a cell wall made of chitin. It has vacuoles, but lacks chloroplasts. … Example: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast).
  3. The cell lacks a cell wall. … Go to 3.
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has a cell wall made of silica, and has vacuoles and chloroplasts. …Example: diatom
b. The cell has a cell wall made of chitin. It has vacuoles, but lacks chloroplasts. … Example: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast).
c. The cell lacks a cell wall. … Go to 3.

tableData.text:
1. The cell has centrioles. … Example: hepatocyte (liver cell)
  2. The cell has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and multiple flagella. … Example: Chilomonas
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has centrioles. … Example: hepatocyte (liver cell)
b. The cell has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and multiple flagella. … Example: Chilomonas

tableData.text:
1. The cell has a cell wall made of silica. It has vacuoles and chloroplasts, but lacks centrioles. … Example: diatom
  2. The cell has a cell wall made of cellulose. It has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and centrioles. … Example: root tip cell
  3. The cell lacks a cell wall, but has centrioles. … Example: skin cell (cuboidal epithelium)
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has a cell wall made of silica. It has vacuoles and chloroplasts, but lacks centrioles. … Example: diatom
b. The cell has a cell wall made of cellulose. It has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and centrioles. … Example: root tip cell
c. The cell lacks a cell wall, but has centrioles. … Example: skin cell (cuboidal epithelium)

tableData.text:
1. The cell has a cell wall made of silica. It also has vacuoles and chloroplasts, but lacks centrioles. … Example: diatom
  2. The cell has a cell wall made of cellulose. It has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and centrioles. … Example: cork cell
  3. The cell lacks a cell wall and centrioles. … Example: skin cell (columnar epithelium)
tableData.hoverText:

b. The cell has a cell wall made of cellulose. It has vacuoles, chloroplasts, and centrioles. … Example: cork cell
c. The cell lacks a cell wall and centrioles. … Example: skin cell (columnar epithelium)

tableData.text:
1. The cell has a cell wall made of cellulose, and has vacuoles and cilia. …Example: plasmodial slime mold (flagellated stage)
  2. The cell lacks a cell wall. … Go to 7.
tableData.hoverText:

b. The cell lacks a cell wall. … Go to 7.

tableData.text:
1. The cell has centrioles. … Example: myocyte (muscle cell)
  2. The cell has vacuoles and cilia. … Example: Paramecium
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has centrioles. … Example: myocyte (muscle cell)
b. The cell has vacuoles and cilia. … Example: Paramecium

tableData.text:
1. The cell has centrioles. … Example: phagocyte (immune responder cell)
  2. The cell has vacuoles and pseudopodia, but lacks centrioles. … Example: amoeba or plasmodial slime mold (amoeboid stage)
tableData.hoverText:
a. The cell has centrioles. … Example: phagocyte (immune responder cell)
b. The cell has vacuoles and pseudopodia, but lacks centrioles. … Example: amoeba or plasmodial slime mold (amoeboid stage)

data.title: Bacillus
data.content: A rod-shaped bacteria species; plural, bacilli

data.title: Capsid
data.content: The lipid-protein capsule that encloses a virus

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: The cell structure that separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell; also called the plasma membrane

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: The cell structure that provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Cellulose
data.content: A polymer that is present in plant cell walls

data.title: Chitin
data.content: A polymer that is present in fungi cell walls

data.title: Chloroplast
data.content: The organelle in plants and certain protists where photosynthesis occurs

data.title: Cilia
data.content: Short microscopic hairlike vibrating structures found on the surface of some cells used to propel the cell along; singular, cilium

data.title: Coccus
data.content: A spherical-shaped bacteria species; plural, cocci

data.title: Cytoplasm
data.content: The area between nucleus and cell membrane that is composed of aqueous fluid with dissolved ions and proteins

data.title: Dichotomous key
data.content: A system of identifying items based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptions

data.title: Envelope
data.content: The structure that surrounds a capsid on some viruses; it is composed of proteins, lipids, and sugars

data.title: Eukaryote
data.content: An organism composed of one or more nucleated cells with a variety of membranous organelles

data.title: Flagella
data.content: Appendages that extend beyond the cell wall and propel the cell along; singular, flagellum

data.title: Golgi apparatus
data.content: The organelle that packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell

data.title: Gram-negative
data.content: Describes bacteria that have a few layers of peptidoglycan located in the periplasmic space

data.title: Gram-positive
data.content: Describes bacteria that have numerous layers of peptidoglycan that lies outside the periplasmic space

data.title: Intermediate filament
data.content: The part of the cytoskeleton that provides support for cells and tissues

data.title: Isoprenoid
data.content: An organic compound comosed of two or more units of hydrocarbons, each consisting of five carbon atoms arranged in a specific pattern

data.title: Lysosome
data.content: The organelle present in most animal cells that contains enzymes to break down biological molecules

data.title: Microfilament
data.content: The part of the cytoskeleton that is responsible for cytokinesis, changes in cell shape,  and cell motility

data.title: Microtubule
data.content: The part of the cytoskeleton that functions in cell motility, intracellular transport, and chromosomal movement during cell division

data.title: Mitochondrion
data.content: The organelle that produces energy for the cell in the form of ATP; plural, mitochondria

data.title: Nucleus
data.content: The organelle that houses the genetic material of some cells

data.title: Organelle
data.content: A specialized structure devoted to specific cellular tasks

data.title: Peroxisome
data.content: The small membrane-bounded organelle that breaks down fatty acids

data.title: Plasma membrane
data.content: The cell structure that separates the intracellular components from the extracellular space and allows transport in and out of cell; also called the cell membrane

data.title: Plasmodesma
data.content: A passageway between the walls of adjacent cells that contains cytoplasm; plural, plasmodesmata

data.title: Porin
data.content: A water-filled protein channel that permits diffusion of ions and small water-soluble molecules

data.title: Prokaryote
data.content: A unicellular organism lacking a nucleus

data.title: Pseudopodia
data.content: Temporary protrusions of the cytoplasm of a cell used to propel the cell along; singular, pseudopodium

data.title: Ribosome
data.content: The organelle that translates messenger RNAs into proteins; ribosomes can be free in the cytoplasm or bound to the endoplasmic reticulum

data.title: Rough endoplasmic reticulum
data.content: The organelle that processes and transports proteins synthesized by affixed ribosomes

data.title: Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
data.content: The organelle that functions in lipid and carbohydrate metabolism and detoxification reactions

data.title: Spirillum
data.content: A rigid, spiral-shaped bacteria species; plural, spirilla

data.title: Spirochete
data.content: A flexible, spiral-shaped bacteria species

data.title: Vacuole
data.content: The organelle that provides storage space for food or water
